body_content.explanation: an organization, business, shop, or farm that is owned and managed by a group of people who also work in it:
examples: Pete worked in a large food co-op in Boston.
Different types of cheeses as well as eggs are sold as part of the farmers' co-op.

body_content.explanation: an organization that owns and manages houses that its members live in, or the group of houses that it owns:
examples: Individual members of housing co-ops do not usually own their homes; the properties are owned by the co-operative itself.
I was looking for somewhere to live and a friend mentioned that there might be space in a co-op.

body_content.explanation: a house or flat that is owned by a co-op (= an organization that owns and manages houses that its members live in):
examples: The maintenance fees on our Manhattan co-op went up 20%.
The houses were renovated, some were turned into condominiums, and others into co ops.

body_content.explanation: a way of playing a computer game in which a group of people play together to try to achieve the same thing:
examples: Split-screen is available for those who prefer co-op.
The game is really best played in four-player co-op, where friends can set out on a quest together.

body_content.explanation: (of a house, a building, etc.) owned by a co-op (= an organization that owns and manages houses that its members live in):
examples: I'm 26 and planning to buy a co-op apartment.
These car parks should have social housing or co-op housing built over the top.

body_content.explanation: involving a group of people doing something, especially playing a game, together to try to achieve the same thing:
examples: The options include single-player, multiplayer, and co-op play.

body_content.explanation: in a way that involves a group of people doing something together, especially playing a game, to try to achieve the same thing:
examples: You might want to play solo first and then grab some friends and play co-op.
Have any of you tried this game co-op?
